channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-8437] Clean up tmp coprocessor jars
item.description:
Users reported that some tmp coprocessor jars are not cleaned up properly, which ends up /tmp folder is flooded.

When a HBase server starts up, we should do some clean up to make sure tmp jar files are removed properly.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
HBASE-6824 introduced a new configuration setting for where coprocessor jars are stored locally, which defaults to $

{hbase.tmp.dir}

/local/, so I think it is safe to clear that dir at startup.

-1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment
http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12582171/trunk-8437.patch
against trunk revision .

+1 @author. The patch does not contain any @author tags.

+1 tests included. The patch appears to include 16 new or modified tests.

+1 hadoop1.0. The patch compiles against the hadoop 1.0 profile.

+1 hadoop2.0. The patch compiles against the hadoop 2.0 profile.

+1 javadoc. The javadoc tool did not generate any warning messages.

+1 javac. The applied patch does not increase the total number of javac compiler warnings.

+1 findbugs. The patch does not introduce any new Findbugs (version 1.3.9) warnings.

+1 release audit. The applied patch does not increase the total number of release audit warnings.

+1 lineLengths. The patch does not introduce lines longer than 100

+1 site. The mvn site goal succeeds with this patch.

-1 core tests. The patch failed these unit tests:
org.apache.hadoop.hbase.client.TestHCM

-1 core zombie tests. There are 1 zombie test(s):

Test results: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/5580//testReport/
Findbugs warnings: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/5580//artifact/trunk/patchprocess/newPatchFindbugsWarningshbase-protocol.html

Findbugs warnings: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/5580//artifact/trunk/patchprocess/newPatchFindbugsWarningshbase-examples.html
Findbugs warnings: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/5580//artifact/trunk/patchprocess/newPatchFindbugsWarningshbase-hadoop1-compat.html
Findbugs warnings: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/5580//artifact/trunk/patchprocess/newPatchFindbugsWarningshbase-prefix-tree.html
Findbugs warnings: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/5580//artifact/trunk/patchprocess/newPatchFindbugsWarningshbase-common.html
Findbugs warnings: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/5580//artifact/trunk/patchprocess/newPatchFindbugsWarningshbase-server.html
Findbugs warnings: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/5580//artifact/trunk/patchprocess/newPatchFindbugsWarningshbase-hadoop-compat.html
Console output: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/5580//console

This message is automatically generated.
Jimmy Xiang, would you mind giving us a sense of what you're doing in the patch?

When a coprocessor is loaded, the coprocessor jar is copied to local from HDFS. The local jar file will be deleted when the JVM exited. However, if the JVM is killed-9, the file will not be deleted. That's how file.deleteonexit works. That means the jar file will stay there forever. This patch is to clean up the local tmp coprocessor jar folder every time when the region server is restarted.

The coprocessor is loaded for every region. That means the same jar could be loaded many times with many local copies. This patch makes the jar load synchronized on the jar path. So that for a given jar path, we just load it once. The existing logic is to let them all load and compete if not already cached, and use the winner one.
+1 on what Andrew said. We just wipe out COPROCESSOR_JARS_DIR on start right?
We didn't wipe it out. We removed all files end with ".jar" and ".jar.crc" under that dir on start.
But just wiping out the directory is cleaner, no? That directory is owned by the coprocessor class loader, so we are sure that there is no other stuff.
Aren't the CRC files deleted when you delete the main file?

Surprisingly, no, the CRC files stay, at least on my box.

Yes, it is cleaner to wipe out the directory. Just want to be explicit since we know what files to remove.
You are on a local FS?
That's right.
Ah so you'll see that all the files have their .crc visible like this, and we're not doing anything special in the rest of the code to delete them.
I see why. I used java File.delete to delete the file. If I use FileSystem#delete, the CRC file should be gone.
Wiped out the dir per suggestions, which is cleaner.

+1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment
http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12582392/trunk-8437_v2.patch
against trunk revision .

+1 @author. The patch does not contain any @author tags.

+1 tests included. The patch appears to include 16 new or modified tests.

+1 hadoop1.0. The patch compiles against the hadoop 1.0 profile.

+1 hadoop2.0. The patch compiles against the hadoop 2.0 profile.

+1 javadoc. The javadoc tool did not generate any warning messages.

+1 javac. The applied patch does not increase the total number of javac compiler warnings.

+1 findbugs. The patch does not introduce any new Findbugs (version 1.3.9) warnings.

+1 release audit. The applied patch does not increase the total number of release audit warnings.

+1 lineLengths. The patch does not introduce lines longer than 100

+1 site. The mvn site goal succeeds with this patch.

+1 core tests. The patch passed unit tests in .

+1
Integrated into trunk and 0.95. Thanks everyone!
